column6:
These guys detail some up-coming stuff. 
http://poetsonfire.blogspot.com/
They held one in November at the Tea Box in Richmond http://www.theteabox.co.uk/ which was good. 
Best of luck
Kim
Whitechapel Gallery near Aldgate East tube station (just off brick lane) hosts this kind of thing.

Hey Robert, you should try Peter Parkers Rock n Roll club on Denmark Street near Charing Cross road. I went there last Tuesday and there was a open mic/poetry as well as live music from a  friend of mine. Check it out!
Thanks for the recommendations.\n\nWill duly check them out. if i find a good space to set up something I'll be sure to post it on here :)
I read your post in a hurry... \nSet one up!! That would be amazing :) The more the merrier, surely. \nBy the way, what are 'bedroom poetry' sessions?

Poetry Shmoetry is a night of poems old and new, learned by heart. It started in Edinburgh and has now started up a London branch as well. It's happened twice in Nunhead and will probably be in Clerkenwell next.\n\nhttp://www.facebook.com/photo.php?pid=1902154&id=507459403#/group.php?gid=199634493064&ref=ts

Bedroom poetry is written in catharsis and should be kept to the bedroom. Not performed. We all write it, but none of us particularly want to hear each others.\n\nThanks Mark, right around the corner from my work too :)

Bang Said The Gun is a weekly open mic night for poetry and spoken word... It's a good laugh, doesn't take itself too seriously, but draws in some awesome people - Michael Horovitz, Charlie Dark... and its only 3 pound. Every Thursday at The Roebuck in SE1

http://www.bangsaidthegun.com/

xx
Aye, one of those gents performed at the Poetry Place recently.\n\nOh that is one for the list. Just rediscovered it after a two year absence. It's become very popular for good reasons :)

For prose go to: http://decongested.org.uk/

'Tales of the Decongested...
...is our monthly evening of live fiction, run monthly at The Wheatsheaf on Rathbone Place. Established authors reading their work alongside emerging talent. The mix is eclectic.'

look at http://www.swisticming.com

under 'culture shock', they list open mic nights/ poetry readings etc that are happening in london

might be worth a gander
:)

http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=241572374932&ref=ts
Anything organised by Utter!!! Y Tuesday, Beat and Bang Said The Gun are all poetry based open mics, google them and you should find them on facebook or myspace.

I am in a theatre company called Poimandres Productions. We will soon be holding auditions in Camden at the Invisible Dot. Check out our Facebook group for more details -  http://www.facebook.com/#!/group.php?gid=186031641639
Hi does anyone know of any cheap bowling lanes, not Allstars? Apparently those one get booked about seven to eight weeks in advance, and I need one soon! Any ideas?
Bloomsbury Bowl is good - Google it!
There's a bowling alley in the arcade near St Thomas's hospital on the South Bank, and there are no queues
Awesome bowling! http://www.shakerattleandbowl.com/london/index.html

I really love Brindisa in Exmouth Market it's great for Spanish cured Ham and some hot smoked paprika. If you're looking for lovely spices go to the Edgware Road grocery I like sumac or whole smoked almond.

There is a pretty great Bengali supermarket on Brick Lane it's got a wide range of spices. Lewisham High Street also has an amazing range of fruit, veg and spices,tamerind, galangal and many boxes of lychees.

I agree about going to the Brick Lane area for spices and ingredients for Asian cooking. It's also worth trying Garcia & Sons which is a Spanish deli on Portobello Rd, i think it's pretty good...\nIn my opinion Borough Market has to be the best. Although it's expensive and crowded it's still an amazing place for rummaging for good food.
How about Shunt?
I think it closed down a while ago.
It's open again!
Not central but I recommend the Royal Navel college in Greenwich Uni. Also try The Trafalgar pub in Greenwich.
Fantastic, thank you. Great news that Shunt isn't closing.
In Soho there is a place called Balans which is open til 5am
A good place for people watching, which seems to always be open, is Bar Italia in Soho
There is cafe opposite Liverpool Station. Although it's not all that nice, it's good if you get the early morning munchies
Cafe 1001 on Brick Lane
I've also never seen Bar Italia to be closed. I know of a seedy place in Shepherd's Bush
There is bagel shop on Kingsland Road/Stoke Newington High Street that is open all night. Highly recommend the salt beef.
Beigel Bake
Vingt Quarte in Chelsea is open 24 hours. It's a bistro that is a good alternative to fast food. I also second the Beigel Bake.
Apparently there are about a dozen ceramic noses of different sizes attached to buildings in Soho - does anyone know where specifically?
About two metres up from the ground on the left hand side of Admiralty Arch
I think there's one in Piccadilly Circus, attached to the Trocadero.
Hi I've never been to a comedy night before, so I'm looking for a good one to go on a Friday. Is the Comedy Store any good?
The Boat Show can be quite cool, and it's on a paddle steamer on the Thames. Cheap too! Try lastminute.com
Great, thank-you!

Up The Creek in Greenwich is good. 10 pound on a Friday plus a disco until 2am. And you can get the DLR or Thames Clipped back to Central London. Loads of big names like Russells Brand and Howard, Jimmy Carr etc. I think their MySpace has the details.
Banana Cabaret in Balham
The King's Head in Crouch End is good
News Revue is a little different
Hey, Amused Moose is pretty good, I went last night and saw Martin Hill and Spencer Brown and had a great time - really dry humour! It's on Greek Street in Soho, and really intimate.
Try Sarastro's!
Guanabara serves really great brazilian food - and they're pretty close too!
For a Martini Bar to die for, and delicious food - Christopher's Bar and Grill on Wellington Street :)
good pre theatre menu at the wonderful mon plaisir, just up towards seven dials

Sitaaray near the top of Drury Lane is this sweet little Indian all you can eat place. They bring around 12 courses - small kebabs done in different styles – and then a couple curry options.  You can then re-order any of your favorite kebabs. The price is fixed around £16 per person (although it’s technically £23, so make sure you ask for the £16 deal). You get poppadoms, dips and naan with it too! Absolutely gorgeous food.
I've been going to mon plaisir for years, the food is amazing. Definitely worth trying :D

32 Great Queen Street is simply stunning; it has this absolutely amazing gastro restaurant on the ground floor :) perfect seasonal, adventurous food and a really cute, tasteful and stylish cocktail bar - not swanky - in the basement for purist cocktails. Definitely a top recommendation.
This is a forum containing photos of secret and hard to reach places in London and elsewhere in the UK -- everywhere from industrial estates to hospitals
This site has photos and info of areas in London in varying degrees of dereliction
I know of one called kitchin-N1 where the lunch buffet is not great, but the dinner buffet is awesome - can anyone suggest others?
There's Rodrizo Rico at several locations:  the O2 Centre, Islignton and Westbourne Grove
There's a brilliant Indian buffet called Indian Veg on Chapel Market - only £3.95 and the booze is cheap too!
There's unlimited dim sum at Ping Pong on Sundays!
Does that happen every Sunday?
Yes - the deal is called 'lazy Sundays' and you need to ask for it when ordering - and you can only order once so get lots! It's about £17 per head.
There's really cheap, fantastic food at Little Bay - there's one in Kilburn.  Suitable for family dinners as well as dates.  I particularly recommend thier moules marinee, it's to die for!
Those who live in Kingston and like Chinese should head to Finesse, I go there regularly and always love it.
There's a good Cemetery at Norwood. But mainly it's got to be Highgate Cemetery....'Victorian Valhalla', as it's known.
Highgate has got Marx's grave and Bunhill Fields in Old St has William Blake's so those are ones to check out if that's you kind of thing!
There is a pretty mad looking one in Stoke Newington - it's called Abney Park

I'd suggest Bunhill Fields cemetery it's on City Road EC1 and  Daniel Defoe, John Bunyan and William Blake are all buried there. Much lot of it is enclosed, but i'd say that it was still worth a visit.\nNunhead cemetery in SE15 is described on one site as  'perhaps the least known but most attractive of the magnificent seven Great Victorian Cemeteries of London'. And there's a conducted tour on the last Sunday of each month starting at the Linden Grove gates at 2:15 - www.fonc.org.uk.

Bunhill Fields is already my fave place in london although i don't want it to be really busy! I'm planning ond doing a photographic study of all the graves in there - fantastic place. You can acess the enclosed bits when the gardener is working on them. I must have walked past nunhead cemetery hundreds of times - thanks for the tip.
Mary Godwin Wollstencroft's grave is in St Pancras churchyard, about five mins walk from St Pancras Station. A while ago, I noticed someone had left some flowers on it, which I thought was nice.
The City of London cemetery between Wanstead and Manor Park is also pretty amazing.
Highgate and brompton cemetry are good - although be careful that you don't lose a limb to the squrriels... no seriously run if they come at you in a horde, it's scary

It's nice to know i'm not the only person fascinated by Victorian graveyards... I was starting to think I was a bit strange! Nunhead is really beautiful. I know a really quirky one - there is a tiny little pet cemetery behind Victoria Lodge in Hyde Park. It's got over 200 graves of cats and dogs. There's no public access unfortunately, but if you walk from Victoria Gate up Bayswater Road towards Lancaster Gate tube you can see the tiny headstones through the park railings.
There's nothing strang, Kerry, that's in my opinion anyway
Bunhill Fields in London EC1 has already been mentioned, but nobody else mentioned one of my favourite inhabitants of that place: Thomas Bayes!
Yep!
Simon, I'm just about to post some of my daughters B/W photos of Nunhead if you wanted to have a look.....

I guess you all know about this, it's a true sightseeing gem!

http://www.shadyoldlady.com/location.php?loc=858

http://www.facebook.com/album.php?aid=93190&id=541276830&op=6#/photo.php?pid=2262187&id=541276830

I love that! Poor Giro was electrocuted... wish I knew how he managed that! Here are some photos I have taken: http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?ref=profile&id=1008550968#/photo.php?pid=30619278&id=1008550968, http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?ref=profile&id=1008550968#/album.php?aid=2035110&id=1008550968
Cheers kerry
City of London Cemetry - Matt beat me to it!! It's right near where I live so I've been for walks there and such. Its huge and really visually stunning.

Wow - none of you have mentioned the best of all London's cemeteries and thats Nunhead cemetery. All Victorian massive grounds and on a hill overlooking london and very spooky. I do a lot of photography there too

It's a bit further out than all the others, but Brookwood down near Pirbright - it's Surrey as opposed to London, but it used to be called the London Necropolis is pretty interesting.\nThis was the largest cemetery in Europe when it opened and had its own direct line from Waterloo, carrying mourners & coffins on the same train; suitably class-segregated into 1st, 2nd and 3rd. Even the coffins.\n
Brockley cemetery SE 4 has fascinating graves and is in a woodland it has amazing birdlife too!
The Place near Euston
Dance attic in Fulham is worth a try
Frame has great facilities though it is not quite central, it's in Shoreditch
The Siobhan Davies studio is in Elephant & Castle. I've never been there so can't really tell you what it is like but I'm assuming it'll be good because it is Siobhan Davies and it has nice pictures
The Latin Dance Academy for latin dance
There's a place on Hampstead Heath High St, next to Base Bistro. It's very popular and open until late.
That place is outstanding!
I agree, awesome place but often busy.

The creperie at Hampstead also has a proper shop next to south kensington tube. Again it gets very busy.\n\nThere is always My Old Dutch on the King's Road in Chelsea. The crepes are huge and they have all sorts of fillings - just as much if not more choice than the Hampstead/Kensington creperie. It's also a bit chilled out too.
My Old Dutch in Holborn has 2 for 1 on mondays.
the hummingbird bakery is infamous but I'm not sure that you can eat in!
You can Eleanor, but there are only a few teeny weeny seats. Red velvet cake...... just the thought of it makes my mouth water!
Yeah the red velvet cake is gert lush. Kitchen and Pantry on Kensington Park Road is a nice, lively notting hill place to go for lunch/coffee.
Even if you don't squeeze into the few seats at the Hummingbird Bakery it is worth getting a take-away cupcake as it comes in a cute box and is way tasty!
Go to Ottolenghi - the best cakes anywhere - and I mean anywhere
Hummingbird is great!!!

Almond croissants and coffees at Caffe Respiro on Kensington Park Rd are amaaaaaaaaaazing, and you can (almost) always get a seat. They also do delicious hot chocolate - and the best panini I've ever had.
May not be cake but... the finest portugese custard tarts, or pasteis de nata (belem), in London can be found at the Lisboa Patisserie on Golborne Rd.

I'd recommend Gails for a girly get together! It's on Portobello Rd on the corner with Lonsdale Rd (and almost opposite Hummingbird if u fancy a cupcake to go!) Gails is a bakery but they have delicious treats and tarts and cakes etc.\nAvoid it on a Sat and go on a Sunday if you have a choice, far less busy.\n202 on Westbourne Grove is also great for a girly lunch. Not cheap and queues though.
Also... try the Grocer on Elgin
Eco is good Italian place. Two good pubs near it are The Sun and The Prince of Wales
http://www.swisticming.com is a good listings site which may help you
The Buona Sera is on Northcote Road has got a good atmosphere and is very affordable
Thanks Yasmin. Has anyone been to either La Rueda or Carmen Bar de Tapas? Any views on them?
I like Thai Orchid in Clapham. Great food, good size portions and a relaxed atmosphere. Good cheap and cheerful night out.
They both do live Spanish music, but I prefer La Rueda.

La Terraza is a good Spanish place.\nThe calamari is a bit rubbery, but everything else is superb and affordable. The mussels in cream are amazing; the spaghetti and seafood paella is also very good. You can also just stay there after you finish eating, and prop the bar up until 2 a.m.
Lola Rojo!
I recommend Mantovani's in South Kensington.
Here are a few of my favourites: Crystal, Wood Green; Churchill Arms, Kensington Church Street and Gaby's, right next to Leicester Square station
Thanks!
Try Little Bay in Farringdon
Artisan at the Westbury Mayfair Hotel is great

The Stock Pot - I've been going here for years with large groups of friends (15+)  because it is so friendly on the pocket. The far is basic but it is very hygenic and clean, and very accommodating without having to book in advance, they have even re-opened the downstairs area just for us! The service is faultless, always polite and friendly and we have never had a bad meal here.
Little Bay is also in Kilburn, it's a really cheap, balkan/european restaurant with great food and beautiful decor
Ciao Bella, near Russell Square, I give it full marks!
LMNT in dalston has brilliant food and very risque toilets, a must see (but not for kids)
There's always Nando's

I visited London in 2008 and went to the Stock Pot whilst waiting to see Spamalot. The food was good.\n\nI went to a Belgian place that was quite gimmicky but fun and with a great beer selection, I remember they served mussels. I guess if a tourist can find it it isn't much of a secret but it was good.
That Belgian place is called Belgos
I also reccommend Little Bay in Kilburn. Also Little Star in Willesden Green and Pierre Victorie on Dean Street - before 7pm you can get a 2 courses dinner for £9.90

I was also going to say Belgos! If you get there between 5 and 6.30 you pay the time you arrived for a meal and a drink - £5 is great value considering the quality of the food! I've also heard good things about the Stock Pot but haven't been there yet. Fire and Stone is my favourite place for gourmet pizzas - they have great deals and vouchers on their website too. The Covent Garden location's nice, and they also have one in Westfield. And the best sushi place is the Japan Centre right on Picadilly Circus - reasonably priced and where all the Japanese go! I'm spilling all my secret places!
Litte Bay in Farringdon is so elegant

There is a great pizza place in Brixton called Franco Manca. It's tucked away in one of the arms of the arcade off Electric Avenue in a really quaint setting. If you're in that area there is also great Japanese cuisine at Fujiyama. In Covent Garden all of the restaurants in Neal's Yard are great, there's one that does the best bread balls! Finally, Tinseltown in Farringdon is great if you're looking for 24 hour, neon, American diner grooves with great milkshakes.
Tayyabs has brilliant food and it is BYO - you can feed 4 people for around £40! But it is very popular so book ahead or be ready to queue

I totally agree about Tayyabs, great curry, great value and you can bring your own alcohol. I go to Mantovani's in South Ken when I've had to stay late at uni and want some ribs, not a place to take a date though...
Ramen Seto and Misato are always full of Japanese students - careful if you're not a big eater though because the portions are massive!
5 posts ago I posted some photos taken there
Brompton is my recommendation

I've heard that the reason there isn't a tube station in Muswell Hill is that they started digging a tube station and then hit a plague pit.\n\nRead the 'Austerlitz' by W.G. Sebald? It's about about a hidden Jewish graveyard in Mile End.

One of the more unknown ones is old Barnes cemetery which is on Barnes common. There are no fences and it has been left to over grow. I stumbled upon it one winter years ago at twilight - it was quite a spooky discovery

It's not really a cemetery, but Westminster Abbey of course has a great number of graves, there's Henry VII, Elizabeth I, Mary I, Chaucer, Tennyson, Browning, Pitt, Dickens, Wilberforce etc etc. Nelson and Wellington are in the crypt of St Paul's
No one's yet mentioned Kensal Green, and that's a goodie!
For me - its all about Highgate:\nhttp://www.flickr.com/photos/onemorechris/sets/72157623070243085/
Putney Lower Common Cemetery is good, but also the really old part of Putney Vale Cemetery (by the crematorium) is very atmospheric...Howard Carter discoverer of Tutankhamun is buried there.

I'm loving Brompton's really fashionable gravestones, some with beautiful painted porcelain flowers, some fantastic art nouveau lettering, and the colonnades. \n\nAlso Barnes Common old graveyard which I stumbled across one winter walk - it's overgrown and lost and very sad - a lot of WWI graves.
There is a good church at St Pancras - it's pretty good and I think they did a lot of Hammer Horror filming there \n\nhave a look - http://www.flickr.com/search/?w=all&q=pancras+old+church&m=text
http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=682906752
There's information about Abney Park, Highgate, Kensal Green, Nunhead, Brompton and West Norwood are on this website: http://www.darkdestiny.co.uk/

There's a massive Whole Foods on High Street Kensington. There are smaller ones around town though, I know there's a small one in Camden Town. Also, in Kentish Town on the high street there's a place called Earth.

I remember there being a health food store on Shoreditch High Street when I used to live there just north of Old Street. 

Other than that, I don't know. The best thing to do is just walk around in your area; that's how I found the two independent ones, but the Whole Foods near High Street Kensington is so big, and they have everything there.
Thanks! No reason to be unhealthy now!
Waterloo Bridge is worth a shot
Try the views from Serpentine Lake Bridge

Great photos and a cheap ride - pick up the commuter boat from Embankment to Greenwich, for £2 with a day underground ticket. See all the sights along the way, off at Greenwich go to Greenwich park to the Queen Elizabeth One Tree seat area - for the best view of London - then return via DLR to Bank or Tower Gateway for more sights and photo opportunities.
You can get the Waterloo Bridge view the other way from Lambeth Bridge too. I've heard Primrose Hill is good, but haven't been myself.
Richmond Hill looking down towards the Thames is brilliant, and sometimes you get to see Mick Jagger.
The bridge in St James's Park.

the foundry, old street.\n\nthey let anyone display their work. all you have to give them is one piece which they can add to their collection and get all your mates to turn up on the opening night to spend money drink...

you can speak to lots of different venues about this, i knew a pub right on the outskirts that let this guy exhibit his work on every wall, and they all had price tags. i would say if it looks like the kinda place where your work would get looked at and look nice then just speak to the owner.
This might not be easy to get to for everyone, but The Brockley Mess in Brockley has a great gallery space

The music isn't a massive strong point but try abu zhad on uxbridge road, by shepherds bush market tube. its a syrian restaurant specialising in all things middle eastern/mezze style. incredible quality of food, v cheap prices and great cosmopolitan atmosphere. no alcohol but give it a whirl, perfect for lunch too!
I'm not from London so I'm not sure which club is best for a student night out. Anyone know of any good ones?
Loads of students go to Cheapskates in Soho. Also, Walkabout on the Strand is good.
Tiger Tiger on Haymarket is great - full of students, especially on Mondays. Very cheesy though, but great fun.
Milkshake at Ministry of Sound on Tuesdays gets pretty packed (I used to work there so I know!). Good promos on drinks too.
Konditor and Cook. Enjoy.
Banoffee muffin at first floor cafe at CX hospital is yum.
Waitrose. :)
Kandana Deli on Kilburn Lane passed Ladbroke Grove tube, W10
Banoffee pie in Cafe Fiori, Leicester Square is amazing.
The Windmill Bar in Cricklewood NW2 is bloody lovely!
I recommend Tartine on Draycott Avenue, South Kensington
The one on the dessert menu at the Cambridge Circus Med Kitchen is amazing!
Banoffee at Balanz on High Street Kesington, it is addictive!
I recommend Annie's In Barnes.
Unsure about the best but I can tell you the worst is served at Canteen
I might be biased as it was my first banoffee pie ever as an american, but I still love the one at The Grove in Hammersmith.
Balans was amazing! That was the best I've had so far, thanks for the recommendation! Bella Italia's is rubbish.
Does anyone know any easily accessible subterranean places in London, or tours which go there? I'm not talking about the Tube, but old tube stations, tramways, subterranean rivers or tramways etc.
I'd recommend the Vaults under London Bridge

Tube Station at Dover Street has no public access. And the last person to use it was Winston Churchill during WWII. It still has all the original posters and walkways and hand-painted signs, his wife's sleeping quarters. Try to have a look for it as the trains decelerate between Green Park and Knightsbridge.
Thanks guys! Does anyone know how to go to the Camden Catacombs?
I agree with Waterloo Bridge.
The view from Serpentine Lake bridge is great

To get a load of great views and a good ride cheaply...pick up the commuter boat from Embankment to Greenwich...cost only £2 with a dayunderground pass ticket, or £5....

And see all the sights along the way.......off at Greenwich go to Greenwich park to the Queen Elizabeth One Tree seat area...for the best view of London....

then return via Docklands Light Railway to Bank or Tower Gateway for more sights and photo opportunities...
Lambeth Bridge gives you the same view as Waterloo Bridge but from the other way around. \n\nAnd I hear the view from Primrose Hill is good tho I haven't been there.
Yes Primrose hill is great!
Richmond Hill looking down onto the Thames is brillaint and sometimes you might even see Mick Jagger
the bridge in st james park is nice
There's this super old mash and pie shop, M. Manze on tower bridge road 87 http://manze.co.uk
good shops too at Chapel Market, Islington and Walthamstow High Street.
http://eastlondonlocal.wordpress.com/2009/04/28/fcookes-pie-and-mash-shop-broadway-market/

Manze's chapel st. is the best in London, maybe even the world - I've been going there since i was 5. im 31 now and since i live further away i can't go quite as often these days. it hasnt changed even a little at all since it's first day. one booth says 'i love david soul' - it's just been scratched into one of the wooded back rests - it's untouched!!! no posh decor - but books shouldn't be judged by their covers - try the pie, liquor and mash! it's like a time machine - jesus, i just wanna go back there now lol. and there's another nice more modern pie and mash greenwich place. it's right by the station. excellent food, a broader menu - specialising in pie and mash. honestly though, manzes is GODLY. best of luck, enjoy it :D
try s&m - they might do pie :)
i don't know all that much about pie... but  'Goddards Pie n' Mas' in Greenwich on a saturday was excellent :)
It's gone :*( replaced by a GBK... damn it. Such a lovely original Victorian spot. Sad. There is some good place around Notting Hill - wish I knew where!
3D Imax
Wimbledon's Polka Theatre - www.polkatheatre.com

Barbican does great family sessions - http://www.barbican.org.uk/film/series.asp?id=813&show=info. Tate Modern and the British Museum are also pretty child-friendly, even if only for a run around and a hot chocolate. Museum of Childhood is great, as is the Maritime Museum in Greenwich - very good hands-on gallery and other activities on Sunday mornings.
Try Chislehurst caves. It's walkable from Chislehurst railway and offers a great guided tour. And it's indoors. Will last about an hour. I took a three-year-old and four-year-old, and they loved it!

www.geffrye-museum.org.uk. Kingsland Road, north of Liverpool St station. It's a converted row of alms houses linked together with each room in the style of the next century. There is modern and interactive computer stuff, a garden and a restaraurant. Very child friendly.
Really depends what age they are and what they're into.
Curzon, get a window seat and coffee, watch people stumble :)
The view would be amazing view from the tate modern top floor cafe, although I can't back that up ; )
Primrose hill without question. Although I wouldn't stay for long in this weather ;-)

http://www.matsuri-restaurant.com/holborn/menu/teppan_yaki_area.php\n\nThis is pretty pricy but it's really good - There's one just down from Highbury and Islington station on the right hand side thats cheaper and nice as well.

I really enjoy Abeno which is on Museum St just outside the British Museum, or Abeno Too near Leicester Square - its also reasonably priced which is a bonus!

Although they do teppanyaki, my favourite dish is their okonomiyaki. (Okonomiyaki is apparently a rural dish, explained to me as sort of a Japanese omelet. It is a base of cabbage, egg and dough with spring onions, ginger and 'tempura' batter.)

www.abeno.co.uk

Benihana is ok, but doesn't have much of an atmosphere (given the area, I think it's a popular 'dinner meeting' venue). \n\nThe place near Highbury and Islington is Sen Nin (http://sen-nin.com/) which is my personal favourite. I don't think teppanyaki is ever going to be cheap in London, but this isn't too bad, and the food is great, as are the cocktails. And the set meals are surprisingly filling! Yum.
I vote Sen Nin as well - and when you go in a group it's great fun as you get your own chef!

We've been to Benihana 3 weeks ago on Friday evening and it was fantastic. I found a cheap deal via iPhone that they didn't have on the main menu - £22 for 8 course meal. It was just enough ..not too much food ..but great quality

I've been to Benihana in Piccadilly a few times (I think there's another one on the Kings Road). The food is always nice but the atmosphere has been really varied. I think it depends on the chef, who's at your table and of course who you're with. It can be pricey too but Janusz's tip sounds good!

Being Japanese, I think Matsuri is the best one in London. Benihana is fun and they make really good effort to entertain you but sometimes it goes a bit too much..(My friend was slightly offended by some of the dirty jokes.. I didn't mind it but depends on the person, right)

You will be sure to have great food at Matsuri. I haven't been to Sen Nin but love to try. 

Okonomiyaki is great but you can make it at home very easy and I found Abeno is pricey for what they offer. After all, Okonomiyaki is so cakked B graded street food they say in Japan like Ramen!

If you like spicy food, you can also head to New Malden for amazing Korean BBQ. My favourite is Su-La but any korean restaurant in New Malden are amazing.
Need one close to an underground station
Gresham Hotel in Bloomsbury is cheap and close to Oxford Circus and Tottenham Court Road
St Christopher's Hostel near London Bridge is very good, I stayed there once. http://www.st-christophers.co.uk/london-hostels
Easy Hotel in Earl's Court is really nice and colourful. Only a five minute walk to the tube, all rooms are cheap and come with an ensuite.
